comments.author: AzureRoxe

comments.text:
+AzureRoxe I think you're kind of missing the point in this... his main 
goal is for the forces of azeroth to fight together. Even if one side is a 
little weaker than the other, that is not basis for trying to get one to 
take over the other. Under Garrosh's rule the horde was extremely weakened 
in and of itself, so that made it a good plan. But in the current situation 
where you have one faction a little weaker than the other, that is not 
basis enough for believing one could successfully take over the other. I 
think right now it's much more likely he'd want the two sides to form some 
kind of agreement to fight together against the iron horde, once they saw 
how big of a threat it is to azeroth.
comments.author: Rainy Jane

comments.text:
+Rainy Jane he would have a reason to if the Alliance was the stronger 
choice. Remember when he said he wouldn't leave anything to chance? He 
wants one side to win, regardless of why and how and right now, the 
Alliance is still the stronger faction.
comments.author: AzureRoxe

comments.text:
+AzureRoxe I think right now we're picking on syntactic differences: my 
point was that Wrathion does not have a specific goal of getting rid of the 
horde per se. It was a strategic point he saw that could result in a 
stronger overall army against the Legion. He has no personal beef with the 
horde in particular. It was just that under Garrosh the horde was already 
falling apart from the inside because people hated Garrosh so much, so the 
horde was weakened and in prime position to be taken over. But now that 
this is no longer the case with the horde, Wrathion has no reason to expect 
it should be easy to take the horde apart necessarily, not moreso than 
taking apart the alliance would be. Also, when you said wrathion 'wants to 
destroy the horde' it sounded to me like you meant "kill everyone who is a 
member of the horde" as opposed to "make it so the group known as the horde 
is no longer a group."  Regardless, even if Jaina becomes the big boss, 
Wrathion wouldn't team up with her against the horde because he has no 
reason to want to do that now. He was never "anti-horde, pro-alliance" in 
beliefs or principles, it was just a strategic point at the time, and it 
isn't anymore.
comments.author: Rainy Jane

comments.text:
+Rainy Jane so the Horde would NOT be destroyed if the Alliance conquered 
them according to you. Ok then, whatever you say.
comments.author: AzureRoxe

comments.text:
+AzureRoxe Not only did I "see the questline," but I've read War Crimes and 
a lot of outside background info about this part of the lore. Wrathion's 
intent in supporting the alliance was not destruction of the horde (in the 
sense of "killing everyone who was a member of the horde"), but for the 
alliance to conquer the horde and force them into submission as part of the 
alliance.Wrathion wanted to do these things in order to cause the alliance 
and horde to become one group, so that as one big group they'd be strong 
enough against the Legion, instead of two smaller groups that kept 
destroying each other. If it meant killing people along the way or forcing 
them into submission, so be it. He felt the end justifies the means, but 
his ultimate goal was protecting azeroth from the Legion, not destroying 
either faction.

Either way, his plan didn't work out in the end, and now he has no reason 
to try for the horde's dismantlement: when garrosh was warchief, the horde 
was falling apart from the inside because so many people were opposed to 
him, so it was primed for the alliance to have a go and dismantle it. But 
now under vol'jin the horde will be solidified again so wrathion has no 
reason to expect it should be readily dismantled. He'll probably want the 
horde and alliance to come to some agreement to fight together against the 
iron horde.
comments.author: Rainy Jane

comments.text:
+Rainy Jane did you not see the Alliance questline for the legendary cloak? 
He wanted Varian Wrynn to kill Garrosh, destroy the Horde and unite Azeroth 
under the Alliance so everyone would be under one banner to fight the 
Burning Legion.
comments.author: AzureRoxe

comments.text:
+AzureRoxe Wrathion is not out to destroy the horde... Wrathion is out to 
train the horde and alliance in preparation for the Legion's imminent 
attack. Presumably he permitted the formation of the Iron Horde so that the 
races of Azeroth would fight against a strong enough enemy they'd be ready 
for the Legion. Personally I think it's an incredibly stupid plot for a 
number of reasons, but that's canon, and so his goal is not destroying 
either faction...
comments.author: Rainy Jane

comments.text:
+The Irishman Except you know, the fact he voiced the Seaman fish thingy... 
So, I guess that's some relevance, however I do think he is probably just 
looking for attention. 

Now, onto your comment.

Two people worldwide on average die every second. So while it's possible 
ten specifically African children died in the five seconds it takes to read 
your comment, it is extremely unlikely due to the (roughly) seven billion 
and one hundred twenty-five million or so people living in the world though 
Africa does have a population of (again roughly) one billion and one 
hundred million so it is possible. If we're going by race it would be more 
likely that ten Asian children died during this time. This is because of 
Asia's population being roughly four billion four hundred twenty-seven 
which is more than four times as much as Africa.

It is also harder to remember something that you've never heard of, though 
there could be ten African children who died, you've never met them, seen 
them, or even heard of them. It's hard to miss things that you didn't know 
about and have never affected you directly. 

My question is what makes African children more special than any other 
children who died or could have died? What makes them more special than any 
other children who died before they could reach their full potential? 
Should it really matter what ethnicity or where the child is located, isn't 
it enough that a child died? In this scenario you're better off just saying 
'ten children died while you were reading this.' That way you're not as 
limited as much by statistics, and people probably won't ask as many 
questions.

captions.text:
• From authentic murder simulators to game
cabinets featuring a butt you can actually

slap, we count 10 of the craziest video games
you'll ever come across

10 - Mister Mosquito,
• Excelizor: So in this PC game you fly

around as a mosquito in a couples house(the
couple is Chinese) and you have to suck blood

from the husband, and there's one particular
part where you go into the bathroom where

the wife is taking a bath(she is naked with
nudity) and you have to suck blood from her

tit. You have to do all this without getting
caught.

• So the main premise of the game is, you're
supposed to go around sucking blood so the

mosquito will survive the winter ahead - came
out on the PS2 in 2001

• It was originally only supposed to be
released in Japan by Eidos Interative but

they wanted a game that'd be quirky, odd but
with fun gameplay that most other studios

would shy away from publishing in the Western
hemisphere

• If you suck too much blood too fast, one
of the Yamada family will notice you and slap

you to death, prompting a game over
9 - JFK: Reloaded,

• Less of a game and more of a playable
history simulator designed to recreate the

events surrounding the assassination of former
president John F. Kennedy

• It puts you in the role of Lee Harvey
Oswald atop the Texas Book Depository - and

using official forensic reports from the Warren
Commission, you'll attempt to rack up the

highest score by aiming with the mouse and
firing 3 times, 2 misses and 1 blow to the

head with a perfect score of a thousand
• There was a competition in which someone

scored 784 points, the closest at the time
and the shooter was awarded $10,000 dollars

for their efforts
• $10,000 for shooting the president in

a death simulator - suffice to say, JFK's
brother was not so impressed by the winning

amount, or the game's existence for that matter
8 - Enviro Bear 2000,

• SubredditReddit (game tagline):Who is
driving the car? A bear is driving the car!

How can that be?!
• Quite simply, a driving simulator featuring

a poorly drawn bear
• The object of the game is to drive around

an open field, crashing into lakes and trees
so that fish, berries, bees and rocks can

fall into your car through the sunroof so
your bear can eat them in order to gain the

necessary girth to endure hibernation
• You hibernate by driving into a cave and

clicking a button
• It has been called the best bear-based

driving sim of all time by website rockpapershotgun,
and driving controls as realistic as you might

imagine if a bear were driving a car by toucharcade.com
• https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NLbFz8jqe6c

7 - Parodius,
• Part of a series of games that were never

released in the states, a parody series lampooning
Gradius and other games at Konami

• You're given a side-scrolling shooter
ship, or a stick man riding a paper plane,

or a flying penguin and tasked with ridding
the universe of random things like lips attached

with robot arms holding cream dispensers or
giant dancing women or Japanese women that

shoot dancing blue rabbits at you
• At the end of one of their recent games

from 2010, you fight a giant robot penguin
standing in front of a black hole at the far

end of the galaxy somehow standing on ice
and he can transform into a fighter jet

• Because that makes sense
6 - Seaman,

• A virtual pet game for the late Sega Dreamcast,
one of the few to use the microphone attachment

- in which you must talk to a continually
evolving creature with a human face, that

of the game's producer Yoot Saito
• It'll transform from a parasite to a fish

and finally into a frog where it'll hop out
of the water and outside of your care

• Speaking of which, if you don't check
on your little creature regularly, it'll die,

and aside from checking the tank temperature
of picking up the creature you pretty much

entirely play the game by giving voice commands
• And for some reason, the game is narrated

by Leonard Nemoy
5 - Harvester,

• A point-and-click adventure game with
a tone similar to the movie Dr Strangelove,

set in the town of Harvest in 1953 about a
guy called Steve suffering from amnesia

• It's a super violent game made in a time
when they were frowned upon - in one scene

you meet an old army guy missing the bottom
half of his body, in charge of nuclear missiles

aimed at the Russians which he alone can activate
with a button - and if you choose the wrong

dialogue option, a video plays of him shooting
you in the head and launching the nukes

• You can also burn down a woman's diner
and force her to commit suicide alongside

her daughter - and if you can reach the end
of the game, you'll find a nice piece of social

commentary
4 - Boong Ga Boong Ga,

• A game developed for Japan in which the
cabinet has a pair of legs and a butt sticking

out that you're supposed to either spank or
jab with your fingers up the butt hole

• You can choose between slapping or poking
the ex-girlfriend to the ex-boyfriend, the

gangster, mother in law, gold digger, child
prostitute, child molester or con-artist with

their reaction displayed on-screen
• Once you do the deed, the machine will

dispense a card that rate your sexual behaviour
and occasionally prizes in the form of a plastic

trophy pile of feces
• And for some crazy reason, this game did

really, really well and was even praised at
the Tokyo Game Show in the year 2000

3 - Chex Quest,
• A 1996 non-violent mod for Doom created

by Digital Cafe to promote the cereal Chex,
and so the game was included in cereal boxes

for free
• The game itself isn't weird, but what

makes this strange is that such a fandom developed
and it was so successful considering it was

a palette swap advertising campaign for children,
even including the original Doom UI hardly

changed at all, and yet this game won awards
and was noted as the first ever video game

included in cereal
• Because of the limitations on their palette

swap and desire for Doom references, bloodied
bodies and twitching torsos from Doom became

goo-covered cereal pieces and twitching corpse
bodies were turned into people trying to extract

themselves from piles of goo
2 - LSD: Dream Emulator

• stormfreeman It's a game entirely based
on making as little sense as possible, you

go through waves of different rooms, some
featuring demonic like creatures which whisper

at you, others having scary faces that jump
out at you randomly, this game has almost

no premise but to try and confuse the player.
• Labelled as a surrealistic exploration

game for the Playstation One only released
in Japan, it's a game they literally took

from a staff member's dream journal and released
as a full-fledged commercialised title - which

might be the greatest thing I've ever heard
• Each dream lasts about 10 minutes, and

if you touch pretty much anything, you'll
be transported to another dream world with

minor differences from anything you've seen
before

• Sometimes you might see a gray or "shadow"
man who glides in one direction with no walking

animation, his head always tilted in your
direction no matter which angle you view him

from
1 - Zoo Race

• A Christian-based game about some people
in a library transformed into animals and

forced to race on racetracks built by Noah
and his sons, who thrown exploding barrels

and try to burn you with flamethrowers or
rocket launchers as you race through various

places and also there are dinosaurs now
• You can catapult your animal miles through

the air to come crashing through glass walls
and then you can have a dance party afterwards

• You don't play this game - you experience
it in the fiery depths of your soul
